Homage to the Bodhisattva King of Long Life. I take refuge in the boundless and limitless great bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas of the worlds of the ten directions.
I respectfully pay homage to the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and all the sages.
Having paid homage to the Three Jewels, I will next repent.
As for repentance, one must first respect the Three Jewels.
The reason for this is:

The Three Jewels are the good friends and fields of blessings for all sentient beings. If one can take refuge in them, then immeasurable offenses will be eradicated and immeasurable blessings will be extended. It can enable practitioners to leave the suffering of birth and death and attain the joy of liberation.
Therefore, I, disciple so-and-so,

take refuge in all the buddhas of the ten directions throughout the reaches of space, take refuge in the supreme Dharma of the ten directions throughout the reaches of space, take refuge in all the great bodhisattvas of the ten directions throughout the reaches of space, and take refuge in all the noble saá¹…ghas of the ten directions throughout the reaches of space.
Disciples!
The reason for repentance today is precisely to say that from beginningless time, we have been in the stage of ordinary beings, regardless of nobility or humbleness, with countless sins.

Either due to the three karmas, we give rise to offenses, or from the six sense faculties, we commit transgressions, or with our own evil thoughts in the inner mind, or relying on external objects, we give rise to defilements and attachments, and so on, up to the ten evil deeds, which increase the eighty-four thousand gates of defilements and afflictions.
Although the characteristics of these offenses are indeed innumerable, if we speak broadly, they can be summarized as three.
What are the three?
First, the afflictive hindrances;
Second, the karmic hindrances;
Third, the hindrances of karmic retribution.
These three kinds of dharmas can obstruct the holy path and the excellent and wonderful things of humans and gods. Therefore, the sÅ«tras refer to them as the three hindrances.

The reason why the buddhas and bodhisattvas teach us to practice repentance and eliminate these three hindrances is that once the three hindrances are removed, the six sense faculties, the ten evil deeds, and even the eighty-four thousand gates of defilements and afflictions will all be purified.
Therefore, disciples!

Today, using this superior and excellent mind to repent of the three hindrances, if you wish to extinguish these three karmic offenses, what kind of mind should you use to enable these offenses to be extinguished?
First, you should arouse seven kinds of minds as skillful means, and then these offenses can be extinguished.
What are the seven?
First, shame and remorse;
Second, fear and terror;
Third, disgust and detachment;
Fourth, giving rise to the bodhi mind;
Fifth, equality between enemies and friends;
Sixth, thinking of repaying the Buddha's kindness;
Seventh, contemplating the emptiness of the nature of offenses.

The first is shame and remorse. Reflecting on oneself, one is the same as ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha as an ordinary person, but now the World-Honored One has attained enlightenment and it has already been through so many kalpas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, while we have become attached to the six sense objects and wandered in birth and death forever without a chance of escape. This is truly something to be ashamed of, to be remorseful, to be embarrassed, and to be humiliated in the world.

The second fear is that, as ordinary beings, our bodily, verbal, and mental actions are always associated with offenses. For this reason, after death, we will fall into the hells, animal realms, or hungry ghost realms and experience immeasurable suffering. This is truly something to be alarmed, frightened, terrified, and afraid of.

The third disgust is that we should contemplate within birth and death, there is only impermanence, suffering, emptiness, no self, impurity, and falsity. Like bubbles on water, they quickly arise and quickly disappear. Transmigrating back and forth is like a spinning wheel. The eight sufferings of birth, old age, sickness, and death torment us without a moment's respite. We should contemplate our own bodies from head to toe, and within them there are only thirty-six substances: hair, body hair, nails, teeth, pus sacs, snot, phlegm, the two intestines of raw and cooked food, the large and small intestines, the spleen, kidneys, heart, lungs, liver, gallbladder, grease, stomach, fat, marrow, membranes, tendons, blood vessels, bones, and marrow, and the nine orifices that constantly flow with urine and excrement.
Therefore, the sutra says:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
'This body is a collection of various sufferings, all of which are impure things.
What wise person would take pleasure in this stinking flesh body?'
Since birth and death have such various evil dharmas, they are very hateful and detestable.
Fourth, as for giving rise to the bodhi mind, the sÅ«tra says:
'One should delight in the Buddha's body.'
The Buddha's body is precisely the Dharma body.

It arises from immeasurable merit and wisdom, arises from the six perfections, arises from kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity, arises from the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, and arises from such various merits and wisdoms. The TathÄgata's body arises from these.

Those who wish to attain this body should give rise to the bodhi mind, seek omniscience, always delight in the pure fruit of sarvajÃ±a, purify the buddha-lands, perfect sentient beings, and be unsparing of their bodies, lives, and wealth.
Fifth, as for impartiality towards enemies and friends, one should give rise to a mind of kindness and compassion towards all sentient beings, without the notion of self and other.
Why is it so?

If one sees enemies as different from relatives, it is discrimination. Because of discrimination, various attachments arise. The causes and conditions of attachment give rise to afflictions. The causes and conditions of afflictions create evil karma. Due to evil karma, one receives the fruit of suffering.

The sixth mindfulness is repaying the Buddha's kindness. The TathÄgata, in the past for innumerable eons, gave away his head, eyes, marrow, brain, limbs, hands, feet, countries, cities, wives, children, elephants, horses, and the seven treasures for our sake and cultivated various difficult practices. This kindness and virtue are truly difficult to repay.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra says:
'If one were to carry him on one's head or shoulders for eons as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, one still could not repay him.'

If we wish to repay the TathÄgata's kindness, we should be courageous and diligent in this world, enduring hardship and suffering, not sparing our lives, establishing the Three Jewels, widely propagating the MahÄyÄna, and guiding sentient beings to enter the right path together.

The seventh contemplation is contemplating the emptiness of the nature of offenses. They have no real characteristics, but arise from inverted causes and conditions. Since they arise from causes and conditions, they can be extinguished through causes and conditions.
Arising from causes and conditions means being close to evil friends and creating all sorts of things.
Extinguishing through causes and conditions means today washing the heart and repenting.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra says:
'The characteristics of these offenses are not within, not without, and not in between. Therefore, know that these offenses are originally empty.'

Giving rise to these seven kinds of thoughts, using the images of the buddhas and sages of the ten directions, raising one's fists and palms together, revealing one's sincerity and transforming with shame, releasing the heart and liver, and washing the intestines and stomach, repenting in this way, what offenses will not be extinguished, what hindrances will not be eliminated?
If one is still lax and indulgent in thought, merely tiring the body, what benefit is there in that?

Moreover, human life is impermanent, like a spinning candle. If one breath does not return, one goes to the grave. The sufferings of the three evil paths are to be personally experienced. One cannot seek release by entrusting oneself to money, wealth, or valuables. In the deep darkness, there is no hope for a pardon. Alone, one suffers these pains without anyone to take one's place.
Do not say that in this life one has no such offenses, and therefore cannot repent with sincerity.
The sutra says:
For ordinary people, every step they take is a crime.

Moreover, in past lives, they have all accomplished immeasurable evil karma, chasing after the practitioner like a shadow following a form. If one does not repent today, evil will deepen day by day. Therefore, concealing festering sores is not permitted by the Buddha's teachings.
Repenting of past offenses is what even the Pure Name values. Therefore, one should know that sinking for a long time in the sea of suffering is truly due to concealment.
Therefore, disciple!
Today, I confess and repent, not daring to conceal.
As for the three hindrances, they are:
The first is the afflictive hindrances;
The second is the karmic hindrances;
The third is the hindrances of karmic retribution.
These three kinds of dharmas rely on each other. Because of the afflictions, one gives rise to evil karma. Because of the causes and conditions of evil karma, one obtains the fruits of suffering.
Therefore, disciples!
Today, with utmost sincerity, one should first repent the afflictive hindrances.
Moreover, these afflictions are reprimanded in various ways by the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, and sages who have entered the truth. They are also called the afflictions as enemies.
Why is it so?
Because they can sever the root of wisdom of sentient beings;
They are also called the afflictions as thieves, because they can plunder the wholesome dharmas of sentient beings;
They are also called the afflictions as violent rivers, because they can carry sentient beings into the great suffering ocean of birth and death;
They are also called the afflictions as fetters, because they can bind sentient beings in the prison of birth and death and prevent them from escaping;
It is also called this affliction to be like a python, because it devours the true suchness Buddha-nature of sentient beings.

Therefore, the six destinies are connected and the four forms of birth are endless, with evil karma inexhaustible and suffering fruits unceasing. One should know that these are all the faults of afflictions.
For this reason, disciples!
Today, using this superior wholesome mind, I take refuge in the Buddha.

I take refuge in the Buddha of Golden Light in the East, I take refuge in the Buddha of Great Mount Sumeru in the South, I take refuge in the Buddha of Wonderful Joy in the West, I take refuge in the Buddha of Endowed Dignified Conduct and Wisdom in the North, I take refuge in the Buddha of Dharma Lineage and Venerable One in the Southeast, I take refuge in the Buddha of Truth Banner in the Southwest, I take refuge in the Buddha of Transforming Bodhisattvas in the Northwest, I take refuge in the Buddha of Wisdom and Diligence in the Northeast, I take refuge in the Buddha of Hair Standing on End in the Nadir, I take refuge in the Buddha of Countless Diligence and Flourishing Virtue in the Zenith. I take refuge in the Three Jewels in the ten directions and throughout the realm of space, like this.
Disciples!

translated: From beginningless time until today, whether in the human realm, heavenly realm, or the six realms of existence, receiving retribution, this mind and consciousness have always harbored ignorance and delusion filling the chest, or due to the three poisons creating all offenses, or due to the three leaks creating all offenses, or due to the three awakenings creating all offenses, or due to the three feelings creating all offenses, or due to the three sufferings creating all offenses, or due to the three conditions creating all offenses, or due to craving the three existences creating all offenses.
Offenses such as these are immeasurable and boundless, disturbing all beings in the six realms and four forms of birth. Today, with shame and remorse, I take refuge and repent.
Furthermore, disciples!

Furthermore, disciples!

translated: From beginningless time until today, either due to the seven leaks one has created all offenses, or due to the seven bonds one has created all offenses, or due to the eight inversions one has created all offenses, or due to the eight defilements one has created all offenses, or due to the eight sufferings one has created all offenses.
Such afflictions are immeasurable and boundless, vexing the six destinies and all four forms of birth. Today, I confess and take refuge in repentance.
Moreover, disciples!

analyzed: ç„¡å§‹å·²ä¾†è‡³äºä»Šæ—¥ï¼Œæˆ–å› ä¹æƒ±é€ ä¸€åˆ‡ç½ªï¼Œæˆ–å› ä¹çµé€ ä¸€åˆ‡ç½ªï¼Œæˆ–å› ä¹ä¸Šç·£é€ ä¸€åˆ‡ç½ªï¼Œæˆ–å› åç…©æƒ±é€ ä¸€åˆ‡ç½ªï¼Œæˆ–å› åçºé€ ä¸€åˆ‡ç½ªï¼Œæˆ–å› åä¸€éä½¿é€ ä¸€åˆ‡ç½ªï¼Œæˆ–å› åäºŒå…¥é€ ä¸€åˆ‡ç½ªï¼Œæˆ–å› åå…­çŸ¥è¦‹é€ ä¸€åˆ‡ç½ªï¼Œæˆ–å› åå…«ç•Œé€ ä¸€åˆ‡ç½ªï¼Œæˆ–å› äºŒåäº”æˆ‘é€ ä¸€åˆ‡ç½ªï¼Œæˆ–å› å…­åäºŒè¦‹é€ ä¸€åˆ‡ç½ªï¼Œæˆ–å› è¦‹è«¦æ€æƒŸä¹åå…«ä½¿ç™¾å…«ç…©æƒ±æ™å¤œç†¾ç„¶é–‹è«¸æ¼é–€é€ ä¸€åˆ‡ç½ªã€‚
translated: From beginningless time until today, I have committed all kinds of offenses due to the nine afflictions, or due to the nine bonds, or due to the nine upper conditions, or due to the ten afflictions, or due to the ten entanglements, or due to the eleven universal defilements, or due to the twelve sense bases, or due to the sixteen views, or due to the eighteen elements, or due to the twenty-five kinds of self, or due to the sixty-two views, or due to the ninety-eight latent afflictions of the path of seeing and the path of cultivation, which blaze day and night, opening the doors to the defilements and creating all kinds of offenses.
Such afflictions are immeasurable and boundless, afflicting sages and the four kinds of birth, filling the three realms and pervading the six destinies, with no place to hide and no place to escape.
Today, I confess and repent before the Buddhas of the ten directions, the honored Dharma, and the noble Sangha.

May the disciples, by the merit generated from repenting of the three poisons and all afflictions, wish to have the three wisdoms illuminated, the three insights clear, the three sufferings extinguished, and the three vows fulfilled, life after life.

May the disciples, by the merit generated from repenting of the four consciousnesses and all afflictions, wish to widely cultivate the four immeasurable minds, establish the four faiths, extinguish the four evil destinies, and attain the four fearlessnesses, life after life.

May the disciples, by the merit generated from repenting of the five hindrances and all afflictions, wish to cross the five paths, establish the five faculties, purify the five eyes, and accomplish the five parts, life after life.

May the disciples, by the merit generated from repenting the six kinds of craving and other afflictions, wish to be fully endowed with the six spiritual powers in life after life, to fulfill the six perfections, not to be deluded by the six sense objects, and always practice the six subtle practices.

May the disciples, by the merit generated from repenting the seven leaks, eight defilements, nine bonds, ten entanglements, and all other afflictions, wish to sit on the seven pure lotus flowers in life after life, to wash the dust with the eight waters, to possess the nine kinds of wisdom-cutting, and to accomplish the practices of the ten grounds.

May the merit generated from repenting the eleven pervasive propensities, twelve sense bases, eighteen elements, and all other afflictions, wish to always use the understanding of the eleven kinds of emptiness to wash the mind in life after life, to be able to freely turn the wheel of the twelve links of dependent arising, to fully possess the eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha, and to have immeasurable merits all be perfected.
The Sutra of the Questions and Answers of MahÄyÄna Lotus Treasure-finder on Retribution, Åšramaá¹‡a Baota then entered a hell of fire pellets facing upwards.
Why is it called the hell of fire pellets facing upwards?

The hell is eighty yojanas long and wide. The iron city and net of the hell emit flames together to burn the sinners. Fierce winds come from the four corners of the city and blow on the iron city, shaking it and scattering it to transform into iron pellets that fly and fall. The pellets have eight sides and are sharp like swords, with flames together forming them. In the sky, they clash with each other like the sound of thunder.
In the south gate, there were hundreds of thousands of sinners, and a Å›ramaá¹‡a entered among them, crying out these words:
What sins have I committed that I have come into this and am receiving such punishment?

He cried out loudly, and his body shook and split open. Smoke and fire came out from his body. He entered the fire, and fireballs from the sky entered through his mouth and came out from his feet. The pores of his body were all burning with fire. For a day and a night, he experienced immeasurable suffering.
Baota asked the horse-headed rakshasa:
What sins did these monks commit to suffer such suffering?
The horse-headed rakshasa replied:

These monks received the Buddha's pure precepts but were not afraid of sin. They plucked fruits from the Sangha's grove with their hands, ate them themselves and gave them to others, not knowing shame or remorse.
For this reason, they fell into this hell.
If they escape from hell, they will be born as humans but be mute and unable to speak.
When Baota heard this, he wept and left.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Buddhist Scriptures, Volume 16
